init_text:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion,

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: it is arrogant and asinine to call any sport too dangerous to be considered a sport.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: This is the same type of argument that can be used to deny someone the freedom to travel, because traveling can have criminal consequences.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: The only thing that makes any sport dangerous, is when it is performed in a reckless manner.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: One cannot simply call a sport, like mountain climbing, too dangerous to be considered a sport, without defining what is reckless about it.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: If one calls mountain climbing too dangerous then they are literally saying that it is reckless to climb a mountain.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: One cannot simply use the term reckless and make everyone agree that they are referring to the danger involved with the sport, without actually defining what is dangerous about

actions.name: text-delete
actions.text: the danger involved with the sport, without actually defining what is dangerous about it.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: not only arrogant, but is also an injustice against us as a free country with the freedom to be different.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: the definition of sport has changed over the years.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: In the words of Joseph G. Rosengren, “the word sport originated in England to describe games that were beloved by both the working and

actions.text: In the words of Joseph G. Rosengren, “the word sport originated in England to describe games that were beloved by both the working and

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: People in the past considered sports to be things like bocce ball, horse and buggy riding, and bowling.

actions.name: text-delete
actions.text: bocce ball, horse and buggy riding, and bowling.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: bull fighting and gladiator fighting; things that many would consider reckless by today's standards.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: Ask a person from the early 1900's what sports are and they would probably say boxing, horseback riding, or hiking and skiing.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: When one calls a sport too dangerous to be considered a sport, they are effectively ruling out many of man's favorite pursuits throughout time.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: Teddy Roosevelt engaged in the "sport" of big game hunting and one of his companions was killed by wildlife during one of his hunting "safaris."

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: Just because someone thinks high-risk activities are reckless, does not necessarily mean everyone else feels the same way.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: The most important thing in determining the value of a sport, is how the participants evaluate it on their own terms.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: People evaluate something based on what they want out of life.
